figure_1.title: FIGURE 1.
figure_1.caption: The Global Emergency Medicine (GEM) Student Leadership Program virtual community of practice (VCoP) structure. This framework illustrates how different groups actively engaged with the VCoP, both learning from and transforming the community. Apprenticeship allowed participants at all levels the opportunity to transition to VCoP leadership roles through active engagement in VCoP activities

claims.sentence: The GEM‐SLP VCoP was structured using the framework of a CoP based on the original theory by Lave and Wegner, as illustrated in Figure 1.
The community's practice—or shared activities, discussions, and resources—consisted of mentoring calls, didactics, and mentored academic projects as illustrated in Table 1 and Figure 1.

It is certainly easier said than done, but I think having a strong cohort that interacts with each other would be incredibly valuable as we are all in the same 1‐2 year window of our training and would feel more comfortable reaching out to each other and collaborating.”



Open in a new tab
Abbreviations: GEM, Global Emergency Medicine; SLP, Student Leadership Program; VCoP, virtual community of practice.Anonymous mentee end‐of‐program evaluations assessing program effectiveness from all GEM‐SLP years to date (2018/2019–2020/2021) are presented in Figure 2.

Mentees agreed that the program increased their knowledge of GEM, with 53% rating this as strongly agree and 32% as agree; 91% agreed or strongly agreed that they would recommend the program to other medical students interested in GEM (Figure 2).

Open in a new tab
Mentee evaluations of the Global Emergency Medicine Student Leadership Program (GEM‐SLP) from the 2018/2019–2020/2021 cohorts (n = 34)Mentee evaluations of the utility of the didactic and mentor components of the GEM‐SLP VCoP from the 2020/2021 year are shown in Figure 3.
Qualitative mentee feedback on both components is included in Table 2 (Figure 3).
The GEM‐SLP VCoP was structured using the framework of a CoP based on the original theory by Lave and Wegner, as illustrated in Figure 1.
The community's practice—or shared activities, discussions, and resources—consisted of mentoring calls, didactics, and mentored academic projects as illustrated in Table 1 and Figure 1.

It is certainly easier said than done, but I think having a strong cohort that interacts with each other would be incredibly valuable as we are all in the same 1‐2 year window of our training and would feel more comfortable reaching out to each other and collaborating.”

Mentees agreed that the program increased their knowledge of GEM, with 53% rating this as strongly agree and 32% as agree; 91% agreed or strongly agreed that they would recommend the program to other medical students interested in GEM (Figure 2).

Qualitative mentee feedback on both components is included in Table 2 (Figure 3).
The GEM‐SLP VCoP was structured using the framework of a CoP based on the original theory by Lave and Wegner, as illustrated in Figure 1.
The community's practice—or shared activities, discussions, and resources—consisted of mentoring calls, didactics, and mentored academic projects as illustrated in Table 1 and Figure 1.

It is certainly easier said than done, but I think having a strong cohort that interacts with each other would be incredibly valuable as we are all in the same 1‐2 year window of our training and would feel more comfortable reaching out to each other and collaborating.”
